_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Bureau of Reclamation (BOR), Yuma Desalting Plant (YDP) has implemented a Risk Management Program to comply with 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, the federal requirements regulating risk management of extremely hazardous substances. The intent of the program is to prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, accidental releases by stating policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other areas addressed in the federal standard.

This Executive Summary includes information required under 40 CFR 68.155.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

BOR implements a scheduled preventive maintenance program, including inspection and testing, to minimize the potential for accidental releases. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) are maintained to enable the employees to perform their work safely and efficiently and provide immediate corrective response to any accidents.

The YDP staff are trained and conduct drills and exercises to quickly implement shelter-in-place response activities in the event of a chemical release incident. Emergency response to an accidental release is also coordinated with Rural Metro Fire Department, law enforcement, and emergency management.



Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

The YDP utilizes chlorine (the regulated substance) as a disinfectant, necessary to promote the destruction of algae, bacteria, micro-organisms, and other aquatic life.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

A Process Hazard Analysis as well as written process safety information has been developed to enable personnel to identify and understand the hazards posed by processes involving extremely hazardous substances. Process safety information includes chlorine information, technology of the process information, and equipment information.

The BOR verifies that the treatment plant (YDP) compli

es with applicable codes and standards and with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices (through review of engineering standards for construction projects).

The Process Hazard Analysis completed for this Risk Management Plan/Process Safety Management Plan (RMP/PSMP) documents staff participation in the analysis and the resulting findings to minimize or eliminate hazards, to mitigate the consequences of hazards of any releases or other unplanned events, and to reduce the likelihood of exposure to chlorine.

Written procedures and information have been developed, implemented, and maintained for each hazardous process, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions.

All employees involved in working with and around the chlorine system are trained in process and safety procedures, including emergency response.

The mechanical integrity of chlorine process equipment is documented and maintained through maintenance, inspection, and testing programs. In addition, a Management of Change program has been established to ensure proper review of a proposed change to the chlorine system.

A pre-startup safety review is performed on new or modified processes to ensure that equipment and construction meet design specifications, procedures and training have been implemented, and hazard analysis recommendations have been resolved.

A Compliance Audit Program has also been implemented. The objective of this self-evaluation program is to ensure that a strong RMP program is maintained, implemented, and followed by appropriate personnel.

Staff have developed a formal documented system to manage incident investigations and follow up. Each incident from a covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage will be investigated and an incident investigation report filed in the RMP/PSMP files.

Management staf

f are committed to involving employees, or their representatives, in supporting the elements of the RMP/PSMP. The following elements involve employee participation regarding the RMP/PSMP:

? Involve employees in the PHA, Compliance Audits, and RMP/PSMP reviews and updates

? Provide employee access to the RMP/PSMP

? Involve employees in the development and updating of training

? Involve employees in an incident investigation

An authorization and permit program for hot work operations near or around the regulated chlorine process has been implemented at the YDP.

Contractors performing maintenance or repair on or adjacent to the chlorine process are instructed in the hazards of the materials onsite, and documentation is maintained on contractor understanding of training provided as described in the RMP/PSMP. In addition, emphasis is placed on knowing how to respond in the event of an emergency.

The YDP chlorine system technologies are not confidential and any information regarding the process or process chemistry is available for review in the RMP/PSMP.



Five-Year Accident History

In the last 5 years, the YDP has had no accidental releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage



Emergency Response Program

The following 3 plans provide a comprehensive emergency response program for the YDP and include 1) RMP/PSMP; 2) the Global Management Services, Operations and Maintenance Personnel, Emergency Response Team (ERT), Standard Operating Procedure; and the Continuity of Operations Plan for the YDP. These plans include the following elements:

? Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases

? Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures

? Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated substance

? Procedures for the use of emerge

ncy response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance

? Training for all employees in relevant procedures

? Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes at the facility and ensure that employees are informed of changes

YDP operators and maintenance personnel are trained to respond to control a release within their capability. However, in the event that the release is beyond the control of the operators or maintenance staff, they would immediately notify Rural Metro Fire Department.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The YDP planned changes to improve safety include evaluating and revising the sign-in and sign-out procedures for YDP operations and maintenance staff working in or around the Chlorine Building and enhancing communication capabilities by installing emergency strobes at facility gates in the future.
